questions.text:
Match the following:
  1. Punishable as per Section 290 IPC
  2. Punishable as per Section 376 IPC
  3. Punishable as per Section 297 IPC
  1. In an empty factory, a man has forceful penetrative intercourse with a woman he kidnapped
  2. In a crowded railway station, an individual obtains sexual gratification when he rubs his private parts against a woman's back
  3. In a lonely graveyard, a person is caught performing a sexual act with a corpse
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-B, 2-A, 3-C

  • Case A is an example of rape, which is punishable under section 376 of the IPC. The definition of rape is under section 375 of the IPC and is as follows- A man is said to commit rape if he has sexual intercourse with a woman under circumstances falling under any of the six following descriptions:
    • First– Against her will.
    • Second – Without her consent.
    • Third – With her consent, when her consent has been obtained by putting her or any person in whom she is interested in fear of death or of hurt.
    • Fourth – With her consent, when the man knows that he is not her husband and that her consent is given because she believes that he is another man to whom she is or believes herself to be lawfully married.
    • Fifth – With her consent, when, at the time of giving such consent, by reason of unsoundness of mind or intoxication or the administration by him personally or through another of any stupefying or unwholesome substance, she is unable to understand the nature and consequences of that to which she gives consent.
    • Sixth – With or without her consent, when she is under eighteen years of age.
  • Case B is an example of Frotteurism. It refers to the act of obtaining sexual gratification by contact with another person (rubbing his private parts against female buttocks, breasts, thighs, etc. in crowds, etc). It is punishable under Sections 290 and 291 of the IPC, with a fine of up to Rs 200.
  • Case C is an example of Necrophilia. It refers to the desire for sexual intercourse with dead bodies. It is said to have a sadomasochistic foundation and that decomposition, foul smell, and coldness act as stimulants. Necrophagia is the extreme degree of sadism in which the person after mutilating the body, sucks or licks the wounds, bites the skin, drinks the blood, and eats the flesh of his victim to derive sexual pleasure. They are both punishable under section 297 of IPC, with a fine, up to 1-year imprisonment, or both.

questions.text:
The synthesis of melanin occurs in melanosomes from a precursor amino acid. Which of the following are not derived from the same amino acid?

DOPA- dihydroxyphenylalanine, GABA- Gamma-aminobutyric acid
questions.solution:
The precursor amino acid involved in the synthesis of melanin is tyrosine. GABA is not derived from tyrosine. Glutamate is the precursor of GABA (γ-aminobutyric acid). Tyrosine is a precursor of thyroxin, epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA).

  • Formation of DOPA: Tyrosine is hydroxylated by tyrosinase to form dihydroxy phenylalanine or DOPA. Tyrosinase is a monooxygenase that contains copper.
  • Formation of melanin: Tyrosinase acts on DOPA to form dopaquinone, which is then converted to indolequinone. The indolequinone is polymerized to form melanin.
  • Formation of catecholamines: Epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine. They are produced by the adrenal medulla and sympathetic ganglia.
    • Tyrosine is first hydroxylated to dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA) by tyrosine hydroxylase.
    • DOPA is decarboxylated by DOPA decarboxylase to form dopamine.
    • Dopamine is further hydroxylated to norepinephrine or noradrenaline
    • Norepinephrine is then methylated by the enzyme N-methyl transferase (NMT) to form epinephrine or adrenaline. S-adenosyl methionine (SAM) is the methyl donor.

The series of reactions involving the production of catecholamines is shown in the image below.

  • Formation of thyroid hormones: Tyrosine residues are iodinated to form 3-mono-iodo-tyrosine (MIT) and 3,5-di-iodo-tyrosine (DIT). These are coupled to give rise to triiodothyronine (T3) and tetraiodothyronine (thyroxine or T4)

Note- GABA is an inhibitory neurotransmitter. It is formed by the decarboxylation of glutamate by l-glutamate decarboxylase.

questions.text: A 13-year old boy presented with mild pain and swelling of his arm. His plain radiograph revealed a well-defined lytic lesion in the metaphysis and a fallen fragment sign. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a 13-year old boy with mild pain and swelling and mentioned radiograph findings point to a diagnosis of a simple (unicameral) bone cyst with a fracture.

Simple bone cyst presents most commonly in the first two decades of life and is more common in males than females. It is due to a defect in the metaphyseal remodeling which blocks the drainage of interstitial fluid. This leads to increased pressure which leads to focal bone necrosis and accumulation of fluid. 

The most common site is proximal humeral metaphysis. They start as metaphyseal lesions but may abut the growing physis.

On radiology, a centrally located, purely lytic lesion with a well-marginated outline is seen. The cyst may expand concentrically but never penetrates the cortex. No periosteal reaction is seen unless there is a fracture. A thinned cortical fragment may fracture and fall into the base of the cyst, referred to as the fallen fragment sign. It is pathognomonic of a unicameral bone cyst with a fracture. It is shown in the image below.

Treatment:

  • Small, asymptomatic lesions in the upper extremities - an observation with serial plain X-rays.
  • Larger lesions (lesions at risk of pathologic fracture), symptomatic lesions, and lesions in the lower extremities:
    • Curettage (with or without bone grafting or internal fixation)
    • Aspiration
    • Injection with corticosteroids, bone marrow aspirate, demineralized bone matrix, or other materials.
  • Fractures through simple bone cysts in the proximal femur and humerus - curettage, bone grafting, and internal fixation with flexible intramedullary nailing 

Other options:

Option B: Osteoclastoma (GCT) usually affects young adults with a peak incidence in their 20's and 30’s. They are solitary, eccentric in location, and most often sub-chondral. They are epiphyseal lytic lesion with trabeculae of the remnants of bone traversing it, giving it a loculated appearance called soap bubble appearance.on X-ray. Periosteal new bone formation is absent.

Option C: Osteochondromas are common benign bone tumors. The lesions consist of a bony mass, often in the form of a stalk, produced by endochondral ossification of a growing cartilaginous cap. Most of these lesions are asymptomatic and are discovered incidentally.

Option D: Aneurysmal bone cysts are benign, locally destructive, multiloculated cysts filled with blood. They are eccentric, expansile, and lytic lesions. Most occur in patients younger than 20 years old. There is a slight female preponderance. The most common sites involved are the proximal humerus, distal femur, and proximal tibia.

questions.text: A 36-year old P3L3 lady presented to the gynaecology OPD with a mass per vagina for the last year. It has also been associated with urinary incontinence since one month. On examination, there is third-degree uterine prolapse. She mentions that she does not wish to have any more children, but wants to retain her reproductive function. Following further evaluation and assessment, an anterior colporrhaphy with the attachment of Mackenrodt ligaments to the cervix was performed. The cervix was not amputated. What is the name of the surgery?
questions.solution:
Anterior colporrhaphy with the attachment of Mackenrodt ligaments to the cervix, without cervical amputation, is Shirodkar's procedure. It is a modification of the Fothergill operation (Manchester operation). It is for women below the age of 40 who have completed their family but want to retain menstrual function.

Shirodkar procedure: Anterior colporrhaphy followed by the attachment of Mackenrodt ligaments to the cervix on each side. The vaginal incision is then extended posteriorly around the cervix. The uterosacral ligaments are divided close to the cervix and are crossed and stitched together in front of the cervix. This is followed by a high closure of the peritoneum of the pouch of Douglas.

The operation preserves menstrual and childbearing functions. The cervix is not amputated which avoids subsequent pregnancy complications. The rest of the operation is similar to Fothergill’s operation.

Options A and D: Fothergill operation is also known as Manchester operation refer to an anterior colporrhaphy with the amputation of the cervix. The cut ends of the Mackenrodt ligaments are sutured in front of the cervix, and the raw area on the amputated cervix is covered with the vaginal mucosa. It is followed by a colpoperineorrhaphy. It preserves menstrual and childbearing functions. However, fertility may be reduced as amputation of the cervix may cause :

  • Loss of cervical mucus
  • Incompetent cervical os
  • Habitual abortions
  • Preterm deliveries. 
  • Excessive fibrosis leading to cervical stenosis and dystocia during labor

Option B: Le forte's repair is done for the very elderly menopausal patient with an advanced prolapse, or for those who are unfit for any major surgical procedure.

Under sedation and local anesthesia, or epidural anesthesia, the flaps of the vagina from the anterior and posterior vaginal walls are excised and sutured together. This creates a wide area of adhesion in the midline preventing the uterus from prolapsing. Small tunnels on either side are left, permitting drainage of discharge. It is not done for women who are leading an active sexual life, menstruating women, diseased cervix, and uterus. Prior to the procedure, a Pap smear and pelvic sonography should be done to exclude possible pelvic pathology.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man was admitted with complaints of diffuse abdominal pain that started one day ago. It was associated with a fever of 38.3°C. There was no history of nausea, appetite loss, or bowel dysfunction. His vital signs were within normal ranges. An abdominal CT scan revealed Hinchey grade 2 diverticulitis. What is the grade indicative of?
questions.solution:
Hinchey grade 2 diverticulitis is indicative of a pelvic abscess.

Hinchey classification is used classification for the severity and complication of acute diverticulitis. It is used additionally to guide the overall management of acute diverticulitis. 

Grade 1

Mesenteric or pericolic abscess

Grade 2

Pelvic abscess

Grade 3

Purulent peritonitis

Grade 4

Fecal peritonitis

The modified Hinchey classification includes Stage 0, 1a, and 1b. It is the most commonly used tool to describe the severity of diverticulitis. Stage 0 is used to describe mild clinical diverticulitis. If CT is performed, colonic wall thickening without pericolic fat stranding can be seen. The ability of a CT scan to distinguish between grade 3 and grade 4 is limited. An accurate diagnosis is made in the operating room. Modified Hinchey classification system is as follows:

Stage Ia

Confined pericolic inflammation—phlegmon

Stage Ib

A confined pericolic abscess (within sigmoid mesocolon)

Stage II

Pelvic, distant intraabdominal or intraperitoneal abscess

Stage III

Generalized purulent peritonitis

Stage IV

Fecal peritonitis
 

Diverticula are saccular outpouchings of the bowel wall. True diverticula are usually rare and congenital and contain all the layers of the bowel wall, while false or pseudo diverticula contain only the mucosa and muscular layers. The sigmoid and descending colon are usually affected, whereas the rectum is generally not affected. Risk factors:

  • Increasing age
  • Diet high in red meat, fat, and refined grains
  • Central obesity
  • Smoking 

Diverticulitis develops as a result of obstruction of the orifice of a diverticulum, with stasis leading to bacterial overgrowth, inflammation, and increased pressure within the diverticulum, causing ischemia and micro-perforation. 

Patients will commonly present with abdominal pain in the left lower quadrant with fever, change in bowel habits, anorexia, and urinary urgency. On physical examination, localized tenderness is seen along with moderate abdominal distension. A tender mass may be palpable. Leukocytosis is a common laboratory finding.

questions.text: A father brings his child with a distended abdomen and poor feeding. He has been on a diet consisting mainly of rice water, after being exclusively breastfed till the age of 8 months. Laboratory investigations show markedly low serum albumin levels. Which of the following findings are not consistent with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a child with a distended abdomen and poor feeding with low serum protein and albumin is suggestive of kwashiorkor, where simian facies is not seen. Simian facies is consistent with marasmus.

Kwashiorkor is a clinical syndrome seen in severe acute malnutrition (SAM). It is associated with pitting edema and apathy and affects children aged 1-4 years.

Edema is most likely to appear first in the feet and then in the lower legs soon developing into generalized edema. Abdominal distension occurs with or without dilated bowel loops and hepatomegaly with fatty infiltrate.

Skin changes occur over the swollen limbs and include dark, crackled peeling patches with pale skin underneath forming patches of hyper and hypopigmentation called flaky paint dermatosis or crazy paving. The skin gets easily infected.

The image given below shows flaky paint dermatosis seen in kwashiorkor.

The hair is dull, brittle, sparse, and can easily be pulled out. It may lose its curl. Alternating bands of light and normal color hair may be seen, known as the flag sign. Children are miserable, apathetic, and often refuse to eat. There is marked muscle atrophy and growth retardation.

The management of protein-energy malnutrition (PEM) is outlined in the image below.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents with abdominal pain, bloody stools, and a tingling sensation in his hands and feet. He is hypertensive and investigations reveal elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, negative antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody, and fibrinoid necrosis on skin tissue biopsy. Which of the following is true about his condition?

choices.text: Can be associated with Hepatitis B

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a hypertensive male with peripheral neuropathy, abdominal pain, bloody stools, and elevated ESR with negative C- ANCA is suggestive of polyarteritis nodosa. 30% of patients with polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) have chronic hepatitis B and deposits containing HBsAg-HBsAb complexes in affected vessels.

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is necrotizing arteritis of the small and medium-sized blood vessels. It can affect the skin, peripheral nerves, mesenteric vessels (including renal), heart, and brain. Pulmonary vessels are usually not involved, however, bronchial vessels may be involved occasionally.

The disease initially starts with non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, arthralgia, and myalgia. Later, depending on the artery involved, the patients may develop the following symptoms:

  • Skin findings- Rash, purpura, nodules, cutaneous infarcts, livedo reticularis, Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Musculoskeletal- Arthritis, arthralgia, myalgia
  • Renal artery involvement- hypertension and renal failure.
  • Mesenteric artery involvement- abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bleeding, and bowel perforation.
  • Nervous system- Peripheral neuropathy, mono-neuritis multiplex, Cerebral vascular accidents
  • Genitourinary- Testicular, ovarian, or epididymal pain

Diagnosis:

  • No specific diagnostic test
  • Elevated leukocyte count, with neutrophil predominance
  • Elevated ESR
  • Hypergammaglobulinemia
  • Hep B and C antibodies
  • Eosinophilia- Rare and if present, suggests the diagnosis of eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg Strauss)
  • Antibodies against myeloperoxidase and proteinase C (ANCA) are negative or rarely found.
  • Biopsies of symptomatic skin lesions, painful testes, nerve or muscle- showing medium vessel vasculitis
  • Angiograms- showing aneurysms of small and medium-sized vessels in the renal, hepatic and visceral vasculature

 The image below shows the histopathological image of an arterial biopsy in PAN.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presented with a history of abdominal discomfort and fatigue. On examination, he is found to have hepatomegaly. The liver biopsy section on staining with Prussian Blue stain is shown in the image below. His liver function tests are shown below. Which of the following is true about the pathology of this condition?

 

  • Plasma iron : 34 μmol/L 
  • Total iron binding capacity : 47 μmol/L 
  • Serum Ferritin : 6000 μg/L 
  • Transferrin saturation : 50% (reference range: 20–50%)

choices.text: Skin pigmentation is primarily due to hemosiderin in the dermis
Iron stains as blue in the nuclei of periportal hepatocytes

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of hemochromatosis. The image shows a Prussian blue-stained section of liver tissue showing extensive haemosiderin deposition stained blue with normal parenchymal architecture. Iron is a direct hepatotoxin and inflammation is characteristically absent.

Hemochromatosis is an inherited or acquired metabolic disorder caused by excessive iron absorption. Iron overload leads to the accumulation of iron in parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas followed by the heart, joints, and endocrine organs. Symptoms usually first appear in the fourth to fifth decades of life. It is caused by mutations in the genes:

  • HJV
  • TFR2
  • HFE - The most common HFE mutations are C282Y, which causes inactivation of the protein and H63D

The manifestations of classic hemochromatosis include hepatomegaly, abdominal pain, abnormal skin pigmentation mainly in sun-exposed areas, defective glucose homeostasis or diabetes mellitus, cardiac dysfunction (arrhythmias, cardiomyopathy), and atypical arthritis. The testes may be small and atrophic resulting in reduced gonadotropin and testosterone levels.

In the liver, iron is initially seen as hemosiderin granules in the cytoplasm of periportal hepatocytes that stain with Prussian blue. As the iron load increases, there is progressive pigmentation of the rest of the lobule, bile duct epithelium, and Kupffer cells.

Iron is a direct hepatotoxin and inflammation is characteristically absent.

In the early stages of accumulation, the liver is slightly enlarged, dense, and chocolate brown. Fibrous septa slowly develop, leading to a small, shrunken liver with a micronodular pattern of cirrhosis. The liver parenchyma is often dark brown to black in later stages due to overwhelming iron accumulation.

Skin pigmentation is mainly due to increased epidermal melanin production and partially due to hemosiderin deposition in the dermis. The combination of these pigments imparts a characteristic slate-gray color to the skin.

questions.text: Which among the following occurs as a result of Bezold Jarisch reflex?

choices.text: Apnea followed by rapid breathing after IV capsaicin mediated by J receptors
Syncope following  prolonged standing and dehydration

questions.solution:
Syncope following prolonged standing and dehydration is known as postural or vasovagal syncope and occurs as a result of the Bezold-Jarisch Reflex. 

Vasovagal syncope can occur after prolonged upright posture which leads to pooling of blood in the lower extremities and decreased intracardiac blood volume. It is exaggerated if there is dehydration associated.

Carotid sinus baroreceptors sense the arterial hypotension and trigger afferent fibers that send autonomic signals resulting in an increase in heart rate and contractility, while pressure receptors in the left ventricular wall send signals that trigger paradoxical bradycardia and decreased contractility. This results in suddenly marked hypotension and the individual feels lightheaded and may lose consciousness for a brief period.

The activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibres in the cardiopulmonary region (e.g. Juxta capillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery) that causes profound brady­cardia, hypotension and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing is the Bezold Jarisch reflex.

It can be elicited by :

  • Substance like capsaicin, serotonin, phenylbiguanide, veratridine
  • myocardial ischemia and reperfusion as a result of increased production of oxygen radicals 
  • Radiocontrast agents for coronary angiography

Other options:

Option A: Tachycardia following acute volume overload is due to the Bainbridge Reflex. The stretch receptors of the atria that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. Efferent signals are then transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase heart rate and strength of heart contraction.

Option B: Hypertension following a head injury is due to the Cushing Reflex. When the intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to RVLM neurons is compromised. The local hypoxia and hypercapnia cause an increase in discharge from the neurons, producing hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration. The resultant rise in systemic arterial pressure tends to restore the blood flow to the medulla.

Option C: Apnea followed by rapid breathing after iv capsaicin is due to the J Reflex. C fiber-endings close to the pulmonary vessels are called J (juxtacapillary) receptors. These receptors are stimulated by hyperinflation of the lungs or intravenous administration of capsaicin. The reflex produced is apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension. This is called the J reflex or pulmonary chemoreflex. A similar response is produced by receptors in the heart (Bezold-Jarisch reflex or the coronary chemoreflex).

questions.text: A 42-year-old farmer presented to your clinic after developing painless otorrhoea and hearing loss in his right ear. Examination revealed multiple perforations in the pars tensa in addition to a purulent, foul-smelling discharge with right facial nerve palsy. Audiometry indicated a 35 dB conductive hearing loss. Which of the following does not constitute an essential part of the treatment?
questions.solution:
The clinical stem consisting of painless otorrhoea, conductive hearing loss with multiple perforations in the pars tensa, and right facial nerve palsy point to a diagnosis of tuberculous otitis media, for which corticosteroids do not form an essential part of the treatment.

Tuberculosis of the ear usually occurs secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis. It is occasionally blood-borne, spreading from a tubercular focus in the lungs, tonsils, cervical or mesenteric lymph nodes. Tuberculous otitis media is mostly seen in children and young adults.

It presents as a painless condition with foul-smelling discharge from the ear, that does not respond to standard antibiotic treatment. A thickened tympanic membrane with multiple perforations in pars tensa of the tympanic membrane and pale granulations in the middle ear cleft is seen. 

Facial nerve palsy is the most common complication. Mastoiditis, postauricular fistula, osteomyelitis are also seen.

Histopathology shows submucosal tubercles with Langhans giant cells and caseation necrosis. Smears and culture of ear discharge may be positive for AFB. Chest X-ray features of tuberculosis along with other evidence of tuberculosis in the body help in confirmation of the diagnosis. DNA probe and PCR from the ear discharge can provide an early diagnosis.

Treatment includes:

  • Antitubercular therapy
  • Aural toilet
  • Treatment of secondary infection
  • Mastoid surgery for complications.

 Reconstructive middle ear surgery is delayed till antitubercular therapy has been completed.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, diagnosed with bipolar disorder is under treatment with lithium for the past 2 months. She now presents with excessive thirst and frequent urination and a diagnosis of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus was made. The administration of desmopressin did not increase the specific gravity of urine. Which is the most appropriate treatment in this case?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate treatment for lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (NDI) is amiloride.

Lithium is a mood stabilizer with a very narrow therapeutic index hence regular determination of serum concentrations is important. Its use is approved by FDA in acute mania and the prevention of recurrences of bipolar illness in adults or adolescents.

Important side effects of lithium are-

  • Fine tremors in therapeutic dose
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Hypothyroidism
  • T wave flattening
  • CNS toxicity manifests as coarse tremors, giddiness, ataxia, motor incoordination, nystagmus, mental confusion, slurred speech, and hyperreflexia.

The development of NDI is related to the accumulation of Li+ in distal tubular cells and subsequent inhibition of GSK-3β, leading to vasopressin insensitivity and downregulation of aquaporin-2 channels. Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that blocks entry of Li+ into collecting duct cells and thus can be used to treat lithium-induced NDI.

Other options:

Option A: Thiazide diuretics may also lead to lithium toxicity. Lithium competes with sodium for reabsorption. Diuresis leads to Na+ loss and compensatory sodium as well as lithium reabsorption from the proximal tubule, leading to toxicity.

Option C: Furosemide is a loop diuretic. It acts by inhibiting the Na+-K+-2Cl- symporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle resulting in increased excretion of sodium, potassium, and chloride. Thiazide diuretics also lead to lithium toxicity.

Option D: Chlorpropamide is a long-acting oral sulfonylurea preferred for central diabetes insipidus owing to its enhancing action on circulating vasopressin.

Related Pearl: PDPH- Post-Dural Puncture Headache

  • May follow lumbar puncture, spinal anesthesia, wet epidural tap (in which epidural needle pierced dura).
  • Onset 12-72hrs and last for 1-2 weeks.
  • Aggravated by sitting and relieved by lying down.
  • Incidence increases with the larger needle, cutting point (in comparison to pencil point) needle, young age, females, pregnancy.
  • Prevention by thinner needle

Management:

  • Supine position
  • IV fluids
  • Caffeine and analgesia
  • Epidural blood patch

Related Pearl: Factors That Can Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Age: Younger, more frequent
  • Sex: Females > males
  • Needle size: Larger > smaller
  • Needle bevel: Less when the needle bevel is placed in the long axis of the neuraxis Orienting a needle bevel parallel with the axis of the spine, such that the longitudinal fibers of the dura would more likely be separated than cut, results in a lower incidence of postspinal puncture headache
  • Pregnancy: More when pregnant
  • Dural punctures: More with multiple punctures

Factors That Do Not Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Insertion and use of catheters for continuous spinal anesthesia
  • Timing of ambulation

questions.text: A 20-year-old girl who is a known case of atopic dermatitis presents with multiple, pruritic pustular lesions for 5 days. Which of the following organism is commonly responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
The above image showing pustular lesions with heavy crusting in a patient with atopic dermatitis is suggestive of staphylococcal infection. Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism to cause secondary infections in the lesions of atopic dermatitis.

However, human papillomavirus‐induced warts, fungal infections, and viruses (such as HSV, vaccinia, coxsackie A, and the poxvirus of molluscum contagiosum) are also frequent pathogens.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the given X-ray finding seen?
questions.solution:
The given image is a barium swallow X-ray showing a feline esophagus suggestive of reflux esophagitis.

The feline esophagus is also known as esophageal shiver. These folds are 1-2 mm thick and run horizontally around the entire circumference of the esophageal lumen. It is thought to be due to the contraction of the muscularis mucosae of the esophagus. This results in the shortening of the esophagus and the bunching up of the mucosa in the lumen. 

The appearance is almost always associated with active gastroesophageal reflux. The findings are transient, seen following reflux and not during swallowing. The appearance is confined to the distal two-thirds of the thoracic esophagus. 

It can also be seen in hiatus hernia and eosinophilic esophagitis. Here, the folds are permanent and associated with strictures.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: A physician observed the following finding in a small child who came for an eye exam. This finding is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given image shows convergent squint or esotropia, which is commonly seen in children with hyperopia, also known as hypermetropia.

Esotropia results due to increased accommodative effort in cases where there is under correction of hypermetropia. The condition may be prevented by full hypermetropic correction. If the child is unable to wear the glasses due to flat nasal bridge or if the child is less than 2 years old, the accommodation may be treated with drugs. Miotic drugs with anticholinesterase activity such as di-isopropyl fluorophosphate (DFP) or echothiophate can be used in these children. Further treatment may include orthotropic training or surgical correction of the squint.

questions.text: A patient with a phobic disorder is undergoing systematic desensitization therapy. This therapy includes all the following steps, except ____.
questions.solution:
Flooding is not a part of systematic desensitization.

Systematic desensitization is based on the behavioral principle of counterconditioning and was developed by Joseph Wolpe. Counterconditioning involves a gradual approach to a feared situation, in a psychophysiological state that inhibits anxiety, to overcome the maladaptive anxiety elicited by that situation. It works best in cases of a clearly identifiable anxiety-provoking stimulus. It has been successfully used in the treatment of phobias, obsessions, compulsions, and certain sexual disorders.

It consists of three steps:

  • Relaxation training - Patients attain a state of complete relaxation and are then exposed to the stimulus that elicits the anxiety response. Relaxation methods like yoga, progressive relaxation, hypnosis, and mental imagery can be used. The physiological changes during the relaxation process; slow heart rate, increased peripheral blood flow, and neuromuscular stability; are opposite to that of the adrenergic response invoked during anxiety. The relaxed state inhibits the negative reaction of anxiety associated with the phobia and this is known as reciprocal inhibition. 
  • Hierarchy construction - The therapist determines all the conditions that elicit anxiety and the patients prepare a graded list or hierarchy of 10-12 fear-provoking scenes in the order of increasing anxiety.
  • Desensitization of the stimulus - Patients proceed systematically through the list from the least to the most anxiety-provoking scene while in a deeply relaxed state.

Flooding involves repeated and prolonged exposure to fear cues of high intensity without a hierarchy. It is based on the premise that anxiety gets reinforced by conditioning when the patient escapes from the anxiety-provoking situation. Patients are encouraged to face the feared situations directly and are prevented from escaping. There is no gradual build-up or use of relaxation techniques.

Phobia refers to excessive fear of a specific circumstance, situation, or object. A specific phobia is a strong and per­sisting fear of a particular situation or an object. Exposure or anticipation of contact with the situation/object triggers an anxiety reaction. This inadvertently leads to panic attacks in people who are susceptible. The person goes to great lengths to avoid this situation or object. According to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders-5th edition (DSM-5),  phobias are classified under Anxiety disorders.

Behavior therapy is considered the most effective treatment for phobias. Systemic desensitization is the most common behavior therapy used for phobias. Other modes of treatment of phobias include insight-oriented psychotherapy, virtual therapy, hypnosis, and family therapy.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy was brought with progressive muscle weakness and walking difficulties. The following finding was noted on examination. Genetic testing revealed a dystrophin gene mutation. On which chromosome is the affected gene located?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the image showing pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles are highly suggestive of Duchenne's muscular dystrophy. It is an X-linked recessive condition. 

Duchenne's and Becker's muscular dystrophy are caused by loss-of-function mutations in the dystrophin gene on the X chromosome. It is one of the largest human genes. Dystrophin provides mechanical stability to the myofiber during muscle contraction. Defects in the complex may lead to small membrane tears that permit the influx of calcium, triggering events that result in myofiber degeneration.

Duchenne's muscular dystrophy is associated with deletions or frame-shift mutations that result in the total absence of dystrophin. Immunohistochemical studies for dystrophin show the absence of the normal sarcolemmal staining pattern.

In contrast, the mutations in Becker's muscular dystrophy typically permit the synthesis of a truncated version of dystrophin, which retains some function. Immunohistochemical studies for dystrophin show reduced staining.

questions.text: A microbiologist conducts a reverse CAMP test and obtains results, as shown below. Which of the following is correct regarding the test?

choices.text: Bacteria A is Clostridium tetani, B is Streptococcus agalactiae
Bacteria A is Staphylococcus aureus, B is Clostridium perfringens
Bacteria A is Staphylococcus aureus, B is Streptococcus agalactiae
Bacteria A is Clostridium perfringens, B is Streptococcus agalactiae

questions.solution:
In reverse CAMP test,

  1. Bacteria A is Clostridium perfringens and 
  2. Bacteria B is Streptococcus agalactiae. 

Reverse CAMP test :

The test is called the reverse CAMP test because CAMP factor produced by Streptococcus agalactiae is used for the detection of Clostridium perfringens from other Clostridium species.

  1. A CAMP-positive group B Streptococcus (Streptococcus agalactiae) is streaked in the center of sheep blood agar, and Clostridium perfringens is streaked perpendicular to it.
  2. Following incubation at 37°C for 24-48 hours in anaerobic conditions, an arrow-head zone of enhanced hemolysis pointing towards Streptococcus agalactiae is seen.
  3. This is because of alpha toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens interacts with CAMP factor and produce synergistic hemolysis.

 

CAMP test :

The CAMP (Christie, Atkins,Munch-Peterson) test is used to identify group B,  β-streptococci based on their ability to form CAMP factor, which causes synergistic hemolysis with β-hemolysin formed from Staphylococcus aureus.

When Streptococcus agalactiae (Bacteria B) is inoculated perpendicular to a Staphylococcus aureus (Bacteria A) grown on blood agar, a characteristic arrow-head zone of hemolysis is seen. The group B streptococci hydrolyze sodium hippurate and give a positive CAMP test.
